For Release Sunday, Dec. 31, and Thereafter
AP World Symposium '90s: South Pacific _ Tiny Islands Come of Age
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The idyllic South Pacific saw its first coups, political violence and secessionist battles in the 1980s. But in the decade ahead, the ``Century of the Pacific'' beckons and the island states expect to have a small but assertive voice in the world. Speaking in unison across a vast expanse of water will be the voices of a new generation of post-colonial leaders with intractible problems: malnutrition, fragile economies with scant export prospects and urban unemployment brought on by villagers flocking to towns with increased expectations. ``One of the continuing difficulties of the small island states is that many will remain dependent on foreign aid, and in some respects more in the past as they continue to grapple with these problems,'' said an Australian government offiical. The decade of the 1980s saw unprecented turmoil in the region. Fiji had two racially inspired military coups. Civil lawlessness in Papua New Guinea claimed more than 50 lives. The capitals of Vanuatu and French Polynesia suffered destructive rioting. Hostage-taking in New Caledonia triggered a bloody French assault. Added to that was a perceived Soviet military threat to the region, concern about Moscow's growing economic inroads and anxiety that Libya was making a foothold in an area better known for its tranquility and palm-fringed lagoons than as a political hothouse. Covering 22 percent of the world's surface, the South Pacific is home to 5 million people, excluding Australia and New Zealand. Environmental problems like depletion of the ozone layer over Antarctica and the Earth's global warming has caused serious concern in a region of low-lying atolls that could be swamped by seas swollen by melting polar ice. The future of Antarctica is assured a big debate as countries like Australia push for protected wilderness status against others who view the world's last great wilderness as a minerals treasure house. ``If for nothing else, that will happen because of the sheer importance of Antarctica in regard to the world's weather patterns,'' said the Australian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Driftnet fishing _ the casting of huge nets over a large area of the sea to scoop up tons of fish at once _ was a problem virtually unheard of six months ago. But it moved into world forums after island governments banded together to draw up an international convention and propose United Nations resolutions that forced Japan and Taiwan to scale down the practice. The 1980s gave birth to an anti-nuclear New Zealand and the declaration of a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone adopted by 15 island states. ``They are increasingly becoming very effective in articulating their point of view and building up cooperation among member states,`` said the Australian official. ``It is a small, but growing voice helped by a new generation of more assertive leaders.'' Against that, he said, ``There are no new bonanzas looming that are going to provide them with any riches.'' The concept of the ``Century of the Pacific'' took a first, tentative step in 1989 when 12 major Pacific Rim countries, including the United States, met in Canberra, Australia, to plan the future. They agreed to meet again in Singapore in early 1990 and probably again in Bangkok, Thailand, later in the year to plan an Asian-Pacific cooperative venture, an idea all agreed was one ``whose time has come.'' The Canberra meeting brought together U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III with his counterparts from Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Brunei, Canada, and Indonesia. They represented 1.9 billion people and $280 billion in trans-Pacific trade, 50 percent more than trans-Atlantic trade. The meeting was described by U.S. State Department officials as the most important economic initiative in 50 years.
